race.name: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder. 50 miles of gravel through Clearfield County.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Pennsylvania countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Pennsylvania event. Rolling terrain with remote access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder is a local event in Pennsylvania—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Pennsylvania countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Pennsylvania gravel race. Worth it for Pennsylvania/Northeast riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Pennsylvania—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Pennsylvania races: Dirty Kanza PA, Trans-Sylvania Epic.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Clearfield County has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Clearfield County has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Parker Dam Gravel Grinder website

course_description.ridewithgps_name: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder - Half Series Route 2024

non_negotiables.why: Pennsylvania rolling terrain requires sustained effort.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: S.B. Elliott State Park provides established venue infrastructure with 7:00 AM registration for 9:00 AM start - tight 90-minute window. Lynn Botelho noted she "remembered to make sure my hydration pack was actually functioning this time," suggesting prep logistics matter more than venue amenities in rural Penfield, PA.

length.explanation: The 52-mile half series sits in comfortable middle ground territory. Lynn Botelho set "a fairly high pace early" knowing she could sustain it over the distance, getting caught by a faster rider at mile 30 who helped her "ride faster" through drafting - manageable length for strategic racing.

technicality.explanation: Course described as "relatively flat course for this part of the world" by Pennsylvania standards, mixing gravel roads with paved sections. Lynn Botelho noted she "descend like a demon," using technical descending skills to pass riders, suggesting moderate technical demands without extreme challenges.

elevation.explanation: 3,500 feet over 50 miles means steady climbing without massive punches - 70 feet per mile average. The full 72-mile route hits 5,707 feet, so you're getting Pennsylvania's rolling terrain. Respectable but not mountainous.

climate.explanation: May 9th date in Pennsylvania means spring weather variability - could be 45 and rainy or 75 and perfect. No historical weather data available for this specific event. Standard Northeast spring gamble.

altitude.explanation: Clearfield County, Pennsylvania sits well below 2,000 feet elevation. Zero altitude considerations - pure power and fitness race without thin air factors affecting performance.

adventure.explanation: Rural Pennsylvania gravel roads through state park lands offer decent scenery without epic wilderness. Course features aren't documented, suggesting standard gravel road network. Pleasant countryside riding without destination-race adventure factor.

prestige.explanation: This is the 6th annual edition of a Pennsylvania Gravel Series race in Penfield, PA. No notable past winners documented, no pro field data, no YouTube coverage. It's a regional series race that hasn't broken into the national conversation.

race_quality.explanation: Trans-Sylvania Productions delivers chip timing, well-marked course, and fully stocked aid stations with reasonable cutoffs. Limited to 300 participants with organized registration system - solid execution of basic gravel race infrastructure without standout operational features.

experience.explanation: You get an event shirt, post-race meal, and awards for top 3 finishers in each category. S.B. Elliott State Park provides a decent venue, but no unique course features are documented. Solid small-town gravel race experience without memorable elements.

community.explanation: Part of the Pennsylvania Gravel Series as Race #2, which creates some regional continuity. Visit Clearfield County sponsors it, suggesting local support. But no rider reviews, forum buzz, or community reputation data available - feels like a quiet local scene.

field_depth.explanation: Field size data completely unavailable, no mention of competitive riders or pro participation. Being a small Pennsylvania town race in its 6th year without documented fast fields suggests limited depth.

value.explanation: Registration includes shirt, chip timing, post-race meal, aid stations, and awards - solid package for what's likely modest entry fees. Three distance options (23, 52, or 72 miles) give flexibility. Early bird pricing with only $10 increase shows reasonable fee structure.

expenses.explanation: Penfield, PA keeps lodging and dining costs reasonable compared to destination races. Visit Clearfield County sponsorship suggests local accommodation options exist - rural Pennsylvania location controls expenses though specific pricing data unavailable.
